title: Monday, 17th September 2018

BE11:27am

Adding a Studios acquisition with c£170m of profits would be a substantial move in rebalancing ITV towards a growth business although it might involve some initial modest earnings dilution.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

And Deutsche:

BE11:28am

ITV is only one of several bidders, it is reported, but we expect the prospects of such a large deal to be received negatively for ITV stock. The valuation looks challenging for an asset with a mixed recent operating performance, other bidders have already walked away, and the deal would involve a material increase in leverage and/or a capital raise. The rationale would be synergies, with increased throughput through ITV Studios and a complementary geographic sales profile. Owning key content rights is a hedge against inflation in programming costs in the future and would maximize the direct-to-consumer strategy that the new ITV CEO has prioritised. But any synergies would take time and combining large production units could have near-term dis-synergies on talent loss and UK independent production quotas.

BE11:29am

And Neil Campling at Mirabaud.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

The US media sector has seen horizontal and vertical consolidation in a race to survive against the onslaught of cord-cutting, scale economics of on-demand VOD, and connectivity changing consumers’ consumption dynamics. It would be logical to expect the same pattern to emerge in Europe given the trends are global. But if ITV was to make a significant deal then perhaps the perennially quoted most likely target of M&A in European media may become an acquirer itself, putting paid to the countless bid spec articles of recent months, indeed years. Back in July when Reuters reported that Endemol was up for sale, a price tag of €2.5-€3B was mooted, with Liberty Global, ITV, RTL’s FremantleMedia and Lions Gate all quoted as ‘eyeing’ the asset. A 10x EBITDA valuation would see more likely a €2B range for Endemol. ITV today has a standalone valuation of 11.1x EV/EBITDA, a diluted EV of £7.4B and total debt to EV of 0.15. ITV has an estimated 5.15% DY and a lot of equity income funds are holders of the stock so the company would need to find means to protect the income stream if they moved down an acquisition strategy. A rights issue might be necessary for ITV to enter the fray for this asset and financial synergies aren’t immediately clear at this juncture.

I'll get the bull case out of the way first. The bull case is, "financing! Super!"

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Here's Cazenove.

BE11:40am

We see this announcement as a material positive for the SXX investment case. Following the capex and procurement update, we saw further offtake agreements as the immediate critical path to de-risking Stage 2 funding. The Cibra agreement now takes total contracted volumes to 8.2Mt which is comfortably above management’s prior target of 6-7Mt, with upside risk given further agreements covering the European region are still outstanding. SXX trades on less than 0.3x P/NPV (pre adjustments from the recent capex update) which, amongst other factors, reflects the markets’ perceived risks around financing. Given the two critical elements required for the next tranche of funding are now substantially complete, in our opinion, we believe there is a legitimate argument for at least a partial unwind of this discount going over the short-term. We remain OW.

BE11:41am

So, given recent questions about the quality of the customers at the other end of the offtake agreements, it's worth giving a few details on Cibra.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Cibra is part of the Omimex Group, a private fertiliser and energy group based in Fort Worth, Texas and engaged in the production of fertilisers in Latin America through the Cibra Group Companies. Cibra is a top six fertiliser distributor in Brazil with annual revenues of c.US$500m. Cibra operates one Single Super Phosphate (SSP) plant, nine blending plants, a distribution center and has operations and warehouses in multiple key ports across Brazil. Cibra holds a market share in Brazil of approximately 4%.

BE11:42am

BE11:42am

We also have Liberum .....

Pharma @Excel OK:Figure 6 in https://www.yardeni.com/pub/peacockfedecbassets.pdfECB ~40%, FED ~20% nominal GDP.Obviously, the figures are reporting different things. Would be interested to know what the difference is between QE spend and balance sheet expansion.
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Aside from downstream investment the Cibra deal is also different from Sirius other offtake contracts in that it incorporates a price participation mechanism into the contract. Pricing is expected to be in line with other offtakes in the early years, however, both Sirius and Cibra will participate in upside from higher prices, further cementing the partnership between the two companies.
One can think of this element also in terms of the value of the transaction; at today's share price incremental $5/t on the price above what it is receiving from other offtakers would repay the investment in around three years on its own, excluding the potential for improvements in other aspects of the business. Of course, as Sirius de-risks its own operation we would also expect Sirius shares to rise.

BE11:43am

The deal takes Sirius' binding agreements to peak sales of 8.2mt per annum. The company has now comfortably surpassed its 6-7mt target and should be in a strong position to fulfill any offtake requirement from the banking syndicate as part of stage 2 financing. A European offtake is also expected to be finalised by the end of October, which should provide further evidence of the size and breadth of demand for POLY4.

BE11:43am

And Shore, which unlike the other two isn't shop.

#REF! I think shore has been shop at some point
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Oh, no, wait. Yes it is.

Excel Developer thanks for that, it is worth totting up all the central bank money as it has reflated equities everywhere.
#REF! or was involved in a raise
BE11:44am

We have previously opined that concluding these agreements could also neuter a line of attack much favoured by detractors and short sellers: questioning the ‘quality’ or creditworthiness of Sirius’s Chinese offtakers. Excluding the Chinese deals, Sirius would today already have 5.7Mtpa of peak contracted volume. That Cibra’a management team previously developed and then sold OFD Holding Inc. (Latin American production and distribution assets outside Brazil) to Yara for an EV of US$425m (as estimated by Yara) in November 2013 should, we believe, go a long way to assuaging any doubts as to Cibra’s competence and calibre, and its choice as Sirius’s South American partner.
All things considered, while Sirius is currently at development stage and still some years from becoming a cash flow-generating company, we believe that an investment in Sirius should become progressively de-risked and enjoy significant value uplift as it advances towards production.

BE11:45am

For independent coverage of Sirius you probably want to go to to places like this: https://ftalphavil...ole-in-the-ground/

Competition in Endpoint appears to be worsening, and we see increasing
evidence of enterprise level next gen players attacking the midmarket. As
such, pricing is anecdotally tough across both traditional and next gen
Endpoint which we believe was a significant factor behind the -5% CCY
Enduser billings in 1Q19

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We see new product releases, namely EDR and Email as helpful, but not
game changing and unlikely to drive significant cross sell, as Intercept X
did in FY18

BE11:54am

Network demand appears to be healthy, in part driven by a firewall refresh,
but we believe physical firewalls are not a major focus for CISOs over
the medium term, as budgets are focused on cloud-oriented products (eg
ZScaler, Okta) where Sophos has little coverage

BE11:55am

Given limited potential for material product releases, pricing pressure and
tough competition, we see limited scope for a major improvement in net
renewal rates and therefore see the FY20/21 renewal book impact as less
impactful than previously thought

11:55 am
BE11:55am

We believe guidance for 2H and FY20 is unrealistic and expect this to be
revised, likely at 3Q results in October

BE12:00pm

Mixed numbers, which RBC can summarise.

BE12:00pm

The results were weak, but with $40m of additional, one-off, depreciation charges, it appears the FY18 financials have cleared the decks for future reporting. The company confirms that CEO Johan Dippenaar will step down once a suitable replacement is named. Q1 production is 10% ahead of guidance. Although diamond prices remain weak, we continue to see significant value in the shares.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Full year results came in below our expectations with EBITDA at $195m vs. RBC $203m, although this is largely due to the stripping out of the to-be-sold KEM asset and associated restatements. Adj EPS at $0.01 was significantly below our $0.08 number, but this was impacted by a $40m higher non-cash depreciation charge related to accelerated depreciation in old mining areas at Cullinan and Finsch. The pre-announced $66m write down also impacted numbers as expected.

Blank canvas Thanks for everything today. Time to hit the turps with a splash of Fevertree
BE12:00pm

The company has disclosed July and August production at 718kcts which we calculate to be at 4.3mcts annualised and 10% ahead of our expectations. We believe this lends credence to the thesis that the company has provided an overly conservative (yet understandable) guidance level for the year. This positive however is offset to an extent by the September tender achieving a -5% decline below the average price in the past 6 months. September is generally the weakest period in the seasonal rough diamond market, but Cullinan prices continue to be at the low end of the range.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

As part of our commodity and currency price update, our FY19 ZARUSD forecast moves from 12.5 to 14.6 (LT from 12.5 to 13.5) and we reduce our diamond price forecasts by 3% (in part by lowering Cullinan specific prices to $131/ct). This sees earnings and cashflow forecasts increase, moving our target price to 60p (previously 55p). Challenges remain but we see the shares as fundamentally mispriced and re-iterate our Outperform rating.

BE12:02pm

Background here is Johan Dippenaar departing post the emergency rights issue, yes?

Tom Dalgleish Burberry could do worse than plastering a Union Jack on everything. Chinese mainlanders love it
BE12:02pm

Here's Canaccord.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

These results paint an underlying picture of operational improvements and the development of a corporate structure more in keeping with a miner moving from being capex-intensive to a stable and larger producer and, hopefully, a strong free-cash flow generator. The positives we saw at Cullinan recently plus the benefits of a weaker ZAR and a more comfortable (though still highly levered) balance sheet must be weighed against the need for Cullinan to deliver larger white and blue stones to take its average price above FY18’s $124/ct average (H2 FY18 was $118/ct). On balance we think there is a positive message in these results, but proof of delivery is needed for sustained rerating.

BE12:05pm

Quick line from Spangel.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

It’s been a long summer and one in which the Company has made zero progress anywhere, in fact, every well intervention appears to result in more questions than answers, and every announcement appears only to sow confusion. To date, the Company has funded itself with convertible securities, but today we learn that it has now fallen out of bed with its funding party. This to us sounds like déjà vu when it tried to escape its obligations under its convertible debt. There is was humiliated as the debt is still on the balance sheet. YA has a long history of execution of these plans, and we would be very surprised if it has got it wrong. Given the management style at FRR, we would put greater stock on it being management’s failure to understand the obligations of the loan instrument - but so long is that list now, does it really matter? We keep coming back to the fact that the basics in this company are lacking. No technical experience at board level, or appropriate experience at any level, to undertake a strategic review of the asset base, hence a lack of understanding as to what to do next.

chad_john Thanks BE
